title: 5 policy suggestions for the ‘European way of life’ commissioner
text:
Incoming European Commission Vice President for 'Protecting our European Way of Life,' Greece's Margaritis Schinas | Kenzo Tribouillard/AFP via Getty Images Unreality Check 5 policy suggestions for the ‘European way of life’ commissioner If Margaritis Schinas really wants to champion Europe, this is what he should do.

Greece's Margaritis Schinas is the EU's new migration commissioner — except he's not.

Instead of giving him a title that makes sense, President-elect Ursula von der Leyen named him "the vice-president for protecting our European way of life," which led to outrage and accusations that she has kowtowed to populist rhetoric. French far-right leader Marine Le Pen hailed Schinas' title as an "ideological victory."

How does the Commission get out of this PR disaster? How about putting forward actual policies to prove that Schinas isn't just a migration chief in a populist's hat, but is actually in charge of championing everything that really does make Europe great?

Here are some suggestions:

1. Compulsory siestas

Who cares about productivity when they're asleep? A Continent-wide curfew would ensure that EU citizens get some shut-eye every afternoon, probably after a boozy lunch. The mandatory scheme, which is already in force during August, would be enforced by a new European Boredom Agency.

2. Free lessons on Brexit moaning

All Europeans love a good gripe about Brexit. But are you making the most of your moaning? Whatever bothers you about the backstop or peeves you about prorogation, this EU-funded training scheme will teach you to take your whining to new levels of annoyingness.

3. Mandatory cheese

Scrap identity cards and make all EU citizens carry cheese. As well as being a homage to fromage, it would save police time as a Spaniard could be quickly identified by the smell of her manchego, or a Frenchman by his camembert, especially during summer. Europe needs stop and sniff, not stop and search.

4. Blame Brussels

This is admittedly a hard one to see the College of Commissioners approving, but is there anything more European than bashing Brussels? A new 24-hour hotline would allow citizens to shout at EU officials about any topic — if they've been dumped, stubbed their toe or forgotten their umbrella.

5. Making fun of America

We've got better health care, higher food standards and markedly less gun violence than our transatlantic cousins. So let's remind them of this thanks to an EU-organized cyberbullying campaign.
description: If Margaritis Schinas really wants to champion Europe, this is what he should do.
